description:
Rhinovirus C (RV-C) is a species of human rhinovirus, a type of picornavirus, that causes common cold symptoms in humans. It is a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus with an icosahedral capsid structure.

RV-C is genetically distinct from the more well-known Rhinovirus A and Rhinovirus B species, with unique genetic and structural features. It was first identified in 2006 and is now recognized as a significant cause of respiratory illnesses, particularly in children and individuals with underlying respiratory conditions.

RV-C utilizes a different cellular receptor, cadherin-related family member 3 (CDHR3), for host cell entry compared to the receptors used by RV-A and RV-B. This allows RV-C to infect a broader range of host cells and potentially contribute to its pathogenicity.

Infection with RV-C can lead to symptoms such as nasal congestion, sore throat, cough, and fever, similar to other common cold-causing rhinoviruses. However, RV-C has been associated with more severe respiratory illnesses, including exacerbations of asthma and increased risk of hospitalization, particularly in young children.

Understanding the molecular biology, epidemiology, and clinical implications of RV-C is an active area of research, as it provides insights into the diversity and adaptability of human rhinoviruses and their impact on public health.
